ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: This is a fun, relatively easy course and a good way to keep using your Italian.
Excellent course, great one to apply towards the major.

So much fun, not an unbearable amount of work (admittedly, the midterm project was a bit ridiculous), but all in all, very fun. Michael is great, and usually the other italian students are a fun bunch, so you should definitely take it.
Maybe. It was nice to keep up my Italian, and we read some interesting things, but I'm not sure I would recommend it, because the curriculum was scattered, and the workload was sort of sporadic.

The class was a lot of work, but Michael's a really flexible, understanding instructor. Don't expect to be able to slack off, but expect to learn a lot and to talk about really old literature.Seriously, though, it's a foundation that's extremely useful for future Italian studies, and one that's rarely taught in a classroom setting. I would recommend the class.

Ital 151 is a really interesting course. We did a lot of translating of old Italian and learned about different forms of Italian literature. Michael Farina is a great professor and he makes the course interesting and engaging. If you haven't already taken a class with Michael, take this course! It is fun, the work load is very manageable, you learn a lot, and you can get your name in print with an official translation.
a fun way to practice italian

For students looking to keep their language skills sharp before they try a literature course in Italian, this is the course for you. It can be very fun. That said, the point of the exercises (sometimes monotonous or un-fun) is solely to reinforce language skills. I think a student who goes into this class with the right expectations will have a fine time.
Interesting readings of medieval italian literature. Too much emphasis on reading and translating, but a good entry to the world of "real" italian literature.
